content.description: Climb the short right-facing corner to a very awkward move left onto flakes. Up easier ground, then step right on the slab under the roof. Pull the roof, get established on a stance to the right, then make a few awkward moves up to a ledge and well-hidden anchor.
content.location: Start at the left of two shallow corners, below a fairly obvious two-tiered roof. The top anchor is up and a bit right from the roof, and not visible from below.

climbs.name: Natasha
climbs.fa: Ben Townsend, Dorcas Miller, Alan Rees, Dale Persing

content.description: This climb follows a left-facing corner with a nice but thin crack. Hardest down low, easy above.
content.protection: Light standard rack to 1", mostly thin pro. Bolted belay/rappel anchor at the top.
content.location: Leftmost climb on the crag. The base of the crag slopes steeply up to the left at this point, making the staging area at the start of the route pretty cramped. Lower or rappel from the two-bolt anchor.

content.description: Follow a right-facing corner up the right side of the big block, somewhat loose at first, to a bulge. Pull up (crux) onto the slab below the roof, then step left and follow the left-facing corner to a ledge with a two-bolt anchor.
content.protection: Light standard rack. Bolted belay/rappel anchor.
content.location: More or less in the center of the crag, before the base slopes steeply up to the left, is a giant detached block. The climb starts on its right side, below a table-sized flake. If you follow the described approach trail to the crag, you should emerge very close to here.

content.description: Start as for Natasha, but immediately step right, using the parallel crack system on the right and the juggy holds between the cracks. Fun moves on big holds. At the top, step left to the anchor of Natasha.
content.protection: Light standard rack to # 3 Camalot. Bolted top belay/rappel anchor.
content.location: Same start as Natasha, below the short left-facing corner near the left end of the crag. Lower or rap from the bolted anchor of Natasha.

climbs.name: Bullwinkle
climbs.fa: Alan Rees, Ben Townsend, Dorcas Miller

content.description: Start up blocky steps to a very short  finger crack, then up to a big ledge with trees. Climb the right-facing corner above (awkward to start, and with inobvious gear) until it's possible to traverse out left (further than you think) and mantel up on the ledge. Continue up fairly easily (bolt) to below the overhanging headwall, then move up right (improbable-looking, but not difficult) to a stance. Up and left (fixed knifeblade) onto the prow, and then up to the anchor.
content.protection: Standard rack (thin cams helpful), bolted belay/rappel anchor. There is one bolt (to avoid placing gear behind a detached block), and one fixed piton.
content.location: Rightmost rock climb on the crag (there are ice climbs around the corner to the right). Start at a short blocky face below a right-facing corner.

pathTokens: 01. Maiden Cliff & Frostbite, Pete's & Blue Vein

content.description:
A 100 ft cliff with both rock and ice routes.  

  In the most recent guidebook (4th Ed., 2010) EVERY route on this little crag got a star (in a "one star" system) Watch out for the poison ivy. 

  Rap the routes to descend.  

  The 2010 guide lists (L to R) the following routes:    Natasha 5.7+   Dale's Variation 5.6+   Boris Badunov  M4    Fearless Leader 5.8   Rocky 5.9+   Bullwinkle 5.10a,  and   Flying Squirrels Under the Moon of Discrimination NEI 4+, M4
